messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 47 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: An ASP approach for reasoning on neural networks under a finitely many-valued semantics for weighted conditional knowledge bases

Paper Abstract: Abstract Weighted knowledge bases for description logics with typicality have been recently considered under a ‚Äúconcept-wise‚Äù multipreference semantics (in both the two-valued and fuzzy case), as the basis of a logical semantics of MultiLayer Perceptrons (MLPs). In this paper we consider weighted conditional ùíú‚Äã‚Ñí‚Äãùíûùíú‚Ñíùíû\mathcal{ALC} knowledge bases with typicality in the finitely many-valued case, through three different semantic constructions. For the boolean fragment ‚Ñí‚Äãùíû‚Ñíùíû\mathcal{LC} of ùíú‚Äã‚Ñí‚Äãùíûùíú‚Ñíùíû\mathcal{ALC} we exploit ASP and asprin for reasoning with the concept-wise multipreference entailment under a œÜùúë\varphi-coherent semantics, suitable to characterize the stationary states of MLPs. As a proof of concept, we experiment the proposed approach for checking properties of trained MLPs. The paper is under consideration for acceptance in TPLP.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 47 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 47"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Peeking inside the black-box: A survey on explainable artificial intelligence (XAI)",
        "Explainable artificial intelligence (XAI): concepts, taxonomies, opportunities and challenges toward responsible AI",
        "Pushing the ‚Ñ∞‚Äã‚Ñí‚Ñ∞‚Ñí\\mathcal{EL} envelope",
        "Inconsistency management and prioritized syntax-based entailment",
        "Joining G√∂del and Zadeh Fuzzy Logics in Fuzzy Description Logics",
        "Reasoning with the finitely many-valued ≈Åukasiewicz fuzzy Description Logic SROIQ",
        "Reasoning within fuzzy OWL 2 EL revisited",
        "Undecidability of fuzzy description logics",
        "The complexity of lattice-based fuzzy description logics",
        "asprin: Customizing answer set preferences without a headache",
        "Semantic preferential subsumption",
        "Rational Closure for Defeasible Description Logics",
        "Defeasible inheritance-based description logics",
        "Towards Rational Closure for Fuzzy Logic: The Case of Propositional G√∂del Logic",
        "Contextual conditional reasoning",
        "On the undecidability of fuzzy description logics with GCIs with Lukasiewicz t-norm",
        "Handbook of Mathematical Fuzzy Logic, volume 37-38",
        "The connectionist inductive learning and logic programming system",
        "A preference-based approach for representing defaults in first-order logic",
        "Fuzzy description logics and t-norm based fuzzy logics",
        "From weighted conditionals of multilayer perceptrons to gradual argumentation",
        "On the KLM properties of a fuzzy DL with Typicality",
        "A reconstruction of multipreference closure",
        "A conditional, a fuzzy and a probabilistic interpretation of self-organising maps",
        "Preferential Description Logics",
        "Semantic characterization of rational closure: From propositional logic to description logics",
        "On a plausible concept-wise multipreference semantics and its relations with self-organising maps",
        "An ASP approach for reasoning in a concept-aware multipreferential lightweight DL",
        "Weighted defeasible knowledge bases and a multipreference semantics for a deep neural network model",
        "Weighted conditional EL‚üÇperpendicular-to{}^{\\mbox{{$\\perp$}}} knowledge bases with integer weights: an ASP approach",
        "A survey of methods for explaining black box models",
        "Neural Networks - A Comprehensive Foundation",
        "Logic programs and connectionist networks",
        "Conditionals in Nonmonotonic Reasoning and Belief Revision - Considering Conditionals as Agents, volume 2087 of LNCS",
        "Self-Organizing Maps, Third Edition",
        "Neural networks and fuzzy systems: a dynamical systems approach to machine intelligence",
        "Nonmonotonic reasoning, preferential models and cumulative logics",
        "Efficient inferencing for OWL EL",
        "Graph neural networks meet neural-symbolic computing: A survey and perspective",
        "What does a conditional knowledge base entail?",
        "Another perspective on default reasoning",
        "Description logic programs under probabilistic uncertainty and fuzzy vagueness",
        "System Z: A natural ordering of defaults with tractable applications to nonmonotonic reasoning",
        "Interpreting neural networks as quantitative argumentation frameworks",
        "Fuzzy OWL: uncertainty and the semantic web",
        "Towards a fuzzy description logic for the semantic web (preliminary report)",
        "A Performance Comparison of Different Learning Algorithms"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 47 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in An ASP approach for reasoning on neural networks under a finitely many-valued semantics for weighted conditional knowledge bases, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
